title: 106_s2674
content: The Act titled "Department of Defense Civilian Workforce Realignment Act of 2000" extends the authority for voluntary separations in reductions in force until September 30, 2005. It also extends, revises, and expands the authorities for the use of voluntary separation incentive pay and voluntary early retirement. The Act extends the authority for voluntary separations in reductions in force until September 30, 2005. It also revises the purposes for Department of Defense VSIP to include restructuring the workforce for various reasons. Installment payments for VSIP can now be made in a lump sum or in installments. The Act extends voluntary separations in reductions in force until September 30, 2005 and allows installment payments for VSIP to cease upon recipient's acceptance of Federal Government employment. SEC. 4. DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE EMPLOYEE VOLUNTARY EARLY RETIREMENT AUTHORITY. Section 8336 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to allow Department of Defense employees who meet certain criteria to receive immediate annuity under the Civil Service Retirement System. Employees must have completed 25 years of service or be 50 years old with 20 years of service, and meet specific eligibility requirements. Employees who meet specific criteria can receive immediate annuity under the Civil Service Retirement System. To be eligible, employees must have completed 25 years of service or be 50 years old with 20 years of service. They must not have declined a reasonable offer for another position within the Department of Defense, and must meet certain conditions for separation from service to qualify for an immediate annuity. Employees can receive immediate annuity under the Civil Service Retirement System if they meet specific criteria, including serving under an appointment not limited by time, being employed continuously by the Department of Defense for more than 30 days, and not receiving a notice of involuntary separation for misconduct or unacceptable performance. Employees can receive immediate annuity under the Civil Service Retirement System if they meet specific criteria related to organizational units, occupational groups, geographical locations, and other similar factors determined by the Secretary of Defense. The eligibility determinations for the annuity must be made according to regulations set by the Secretary of Defense. The term 'major organizational adjustment' includes reorganization, reduction in force, transfer of function, and workforce restructuring to meet mission needs. Employees of the Department of Defense can receive immediate annuity if they are separated after completing 25 years of service or reaching 50 years of age with 20 years of service. This is part of a workforce restructuring to meet mission needs or reduce positions. An employee with years of service can receive an immediate annuity if separated involuntarily and not declined a suitable job offer within the Department of Defense. An employee can receive an immediate annuity if separated voluntarily during a major organizational adjustment in the Department of Defense, with continuous employment of more than 30 days and serving under a non-time-limited appointment. An employee can receive an immediate annuity if separated voluntarily during a major organizational adjustment in the Department of Defense, with continuous employment of more than 30 days and serving under a non-time-limited appointment. The eligibility criteria include not being in receipt of a decision notice of involuntary separation for misconduct or unacceptable performance, and being within the scope of an offer of voluntary early retirement based on specific objective criteria determined by the Secretary of Defense. Determinations for eligibility are made according to regulations prescribed by the Secretary of Defense. The term 'major organizational adjustment' in the Department of Defense includes reorganization, reduction in force, transfer of function, and workforce restructuring to meet mission needs, achieve reductions in strength, correct skill imbalances, or reduce high-grade positions. Amendments are made to sections 8339(h) and 8464(a)(1)(A)(i) of the title. The amendments made by this section will take effect on October 1, 2000, and apply to voluntary early retirement approvals made on or after that date. SEC. 5. RESTRICTIONS ON PAYMENTS FOR ACADEMIC TRAINING. Sources of Postsecondary Education under section 4107 of title 5, United States Code, are amended to include courses from institutions not accredited by a national or regional body, with exceptions. Waiver of restrictions on degree training is also addressed. The amendment to section 4107 of title 5, United States Code allows for waiver of restrictions on degree training if it is part of a professional development program approved by the agency head. Conforming and clerical amendments are also made to the section. SEC. 6. STRATEGIC PLAN. The Secretary of Defense must submit a strategic plan to Congress within six months of the enactment of the Act, detailing the impact on Department of Defense employees. The plan must align with the Department of Defense's existing strategic plan. The appropriate committees for this section are the Senate's Committee on Armed Services and Committee on Governmental Affairs. The Committee on Armed Services and the Committee on Government Reform of the House of Representatives are involved in major workforce restructuring to meet mission needs, reduce strength, correct skill imbalances, and eliminate high-grade positions. Conforming amendments are made to sections 8339(h) and 8464(a)(1)(A)(i) of the title. The effective date and applicability of the amendments are specified. The amendments made by this section will take effect on October 1, 2000, and will apply to approvals for voluntary early retirement made on or after that date. SEC. 5. RESTRICTIONS ON PAYMENTS FOR ACADEMIC TRAINING. Sources of Postsecondary Education under section 4107 of title 5, United States Code, are amended to include courses from institutions not accredited by a national or regional body, with exceptions. Waiver of restrictions on degree training is also addressed. The amendment to section 4107 of title 5, United States Code allows for degree training waivers if part of an approved professional development program. Conforming and clerical amendments are also made to the section. SEC. 6. STRATEGIC PLAN. The Secretary of Defense must submit a strategic plan to Congress within six months of the enactment of this Act, detailing the impact on Department of Defense employees. The plan must align with the Department of Defense's existing strategic plan. The appropriate committees for this section are the Senate's Committee on Armed Services and Committee on Governmental Affairs. The Senate's Committee on Armed Services and the House of Representatives' Committee on Government Reform are responsible for overseeing governmental affairs related to the Department of Defense.
